data.headline: Nasdaq rose 1.1% and S&P 500 gained 0.6%, both approaching record highs, while the Dow and small caps also advanced
bullets: Software and broader tech sectors outperformed, with Oracle soaring 11% on strong AI demand and upbeat guidance
AppLovin surged over 14% as traders viewed last week's selloff as overdone
Nvidia climbed after Bank of America reiterated its buy rating, while Palantir and chip stocks also firmed
Ciena jumped on stock-specific momentum, and Valaris rallied on deal news
Kroger traded higher, while Hims & Hers tumbled on concerns over Novo Nordisk's weight-loss competition
Nexstar and Tegna rallied after a Trump merger endorsement, while Kyndryl slid on earnings and an SEC-linked accounting review
Low trading volumes and global momentum, including a 5% Nikkei rally after Japan's ruling party election win, supported risk appetite
Bitcoin and precious metals stabilized, and a softer dollar underpinned broader market strength
Traders focused on tech rotation ahead of delayed January nonfarm payrolls, CPI, and retail sales data later this week
